thread.title: Delta still the best at on-time arrivals in June
thread.title_full: Delta still the best at on-time arrivals in June

author: Lewis Lazare
title: Delta still the best at on-time arrivals in June
text:
See All Homes of the Day Southwest finished June with 71.8 percent of flights arriving on time, according to FlightView, down from 78.3 percent in May. Noted the Southwest spokesman: "Many severe storms that impacted the central United States had an overall impact on our on-time performance last month." AA finished June with 71.9 percent of flights arriving on time, down from 75.2 percent in May. A flight that arrives within 14 minutes of its scheduled arrival time is considered on-time. Every major domestic carrier's on-time performance actually suffered in June compared with the May results. But AA had the smallest drop, suggesting AA CEO Doug Parker , still relatively new to the role, may be on his own mission to make his airline, now the world's largest, an on-time arrival performance leader. But by far the worst on-time arrival performance among the four largest domestic carriers was notched by Chicago-based United Airlines (NYSE: UAL). Though UA has not been talking a lot about its on-time performance in recent months — preferring instead to focus on airport enhancements and onboard amenities and food upgrades — the carrier fell to a pretty poor 66.5 percent of flights arriving on time in June, compared to 75.0 percent in May. Asked about on-time arrival results for June, a United spokesman said today: "The biggest driver was weather, with United seeing the highest rate of weather-related delays and cancellations since December, 2008. For the first half of June alone, thunderstorms hit at least one United hub 14 of the first 15 days of the month."
